awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Baseline for Antarctic Blue and Fin Whales
awd_abstract_narration:
Blue and fin whales are the two largest animals on the planet, and the two largest krill predators in the Southern Ocean. Commercial whaling in Antarctic waters started in the early 1900?s, and by the 1970's whale populations were reduced from thousands to only a few hundred individuals. The absence of data about whale biology and ecology prior to these large population reductions has limited our understanding of how the ecosystem functioned when cetacean populations were more robust. However, an archive of baleen plates from 800 Antarctic blue and fin whales harvested between 1946 and 1948 was recently rediscovered in the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History that will shed insight into historic whale ecology. As baleen grows, it incorporates circulating hormones, and compounds from the whale's diet, recording continuous biological and oceanographic information across multiple years. This project will apply a suite of modern molecular techniques to these archived specimens to ask how blue and fin whale foraging and reproduction responded to climate variability, changes at the base of the food web, and whaling activities in the early 1940s. By comparison with more modern datasets, these investigations will fill major gaps in understanding of the largest krill predators, their response to disturbance and environmental change, and the impact that commercial whaling has had on the structure and function of the Antarctic marine ecosystem. This project will improve stem education through annual programming for middle and high school girls in partnership with UNCW's Marine Quest program. Public outreach will occur through partnerships with the Smithsonian and the International Association of Antarctic Tour Operators to deliver emerging research on Antarctic ecosystems and highlight the contemporary relevance and scientific value of museum collections. 

Examination of past conditions and adaptations of polar biota is fundamental to predictions of future climate change scenarios. The baleen record that will be used in this study forms an ideal experimental platform for studying bottom-up, top-down and anthropogenic impacts on blue and fin whales. This historic baleen archive includes years with strong climate and temperature anomalies allowing the influence of climate variability on predators and the ecosystems that support them to be examined. Additionally, the impact of commercial whaling on whale stress levels will be investigated by comparing years of intensive whaling with the non-whaling years of WWII, both of which are captured in the time series. There are three main approaches to this project. First, bulk stable isotope analysis will be used to examine the trophic dynamics of Antarctic blue and fin whales. Second, compound-specific stable isotope analyses (CSIA-AA) will characterize the biogeochemistry of the base of the Antarctic food web. Finally, analyses of hormone levels in baleen will reveal differences in stress levels and reproductive status of individuals, and inform understanding of cetacean population biology. This project will generate a new public data archive to foster research opportunities across various components of the OPP program, all free from the logistical constraints of Antarctic field work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project were to investigate patterns of stress and reproduction in large marine predators of the past, specifically from baleen of Antarctic blue whales and fin whales that were collected during the 1940s. Baleen is a keratin structure that grows from the upper palate of blue and fin whales, and a single long piece ("plate") of baleen grows slowly over time, accumuilating hormones as it grows. One baleen plate thus contains information about the last several years of the whale's life. By utilizing rare WWII-era baleen specimens housed at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, we were able to collect small specimens of baleen powder from 34 baleen plates (i.e., from 34 whales) each sampled every 1 cm along the length of the baleen. Each plate was nearly a meter long and generated many samples; overall, we analyzed a grand total of 2704 baleen-powder samples. Each powder sample was then analyzed for cortisol and corticosterone (stress hormones), as well as progesterone (the major pregnancy hormone of mammals) for female whales, and testosterone (the major hormone of the male reproductive system) for male whales. 

Our main project findings were as follows: First, female blue and fin whales had much more variable reproductive cycles that had been expected. Rather than the regular two-year pregnancy interval that is often assumed to be the norm for blue and fin whales (i.e. one year pregnant, then one year nursing), some females began a pregnancy every year, others had erratic unexpected long intervals between pregnancies, and some went up to seven years with no pregnancies. This finding indicates unexpected flexibility in female whale reproduction. Adult males, in contrast, tended to show a regular annual elevation of testosterone, assumed to occur during or just prior to an annual breeding season. The onset of these testosterone cycles in young males may provide information about age of sexual maturity. As for the two stress hormones, corticosterone appeared to be the major (more abundant) stress hormone in baleen of both species, i.e. corticosterone was consistently higher than cortisol, in both sexes and both species. Corticosterone showed pronounced variation, some of which was related to the reproductive hormones (i.e., reproduction itself is a type of stressor) but a portion of the corticosterone variation was instead attributable to calendar year. That is, across all whales, corticosterone was low in certain years and higher in other years. This pattern did not correlate with any known ecological variables, but instead appeared related to the occurrence of World War II. Specifically, average corticosterone was lowest during 1942-1945, years when Antarctic commercial whaling was halted due to World War II, and corticosterone then rose in most individuals in 1946, the year when commercial whaling resumed in the Antarctic. This finding indicates the sensitivity of these large predators to human impacts, even in remote environments such as the Antarctic. Overall, we succeeded in reaching our project goals of better understanding stress and reproduction in marine predators of the past. 

This project has resulted in fourteen peer-reviewed publications and fourteen presentations at scientific conferences, as well as training of five undergaduates, four graduate students and two post-doctoral fellows. Two of the graduate students had theses that were fully derived from this project, and both students have completed their degrees. We also developed and tested new lab methods for analysis of hormones in keratin tissues, which has resulted in new research not only on other whale species, but also in new methods to study stress and reproduction in many other animals and other keratin sample types (e.g., rhinoceros horn, bird feather). We also developed new statistical analysis techniques for handling data from an individual animal that may include hundreds of data points stretching across many years. Our impact thus extends to multiple other disciplines of science. Finally, our project also demonstrates that even 75-year-old museum specimens still retain valuable biological and ecological data, illustrating the value of natural history museums for research.

Our scientific information was disseminated to the public via many avenues including: new teaching modules for undergraduates at the Smithsonian-Mason School of Conservation; new whale exhibits, signage and public symposia at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History; backstage tours of the Smithsonian research archives for a variety of audiences; and multiple seminars, webinars, and long-format science journalism articles.


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Kathleen E Hunt
